content:
Ankur Warikoo
Ankur Warikoo "I could’ve done that."

Said by someone who didn’t see the late nights.
Didn’t sit through the rejections.
Didn’t risk being wrong in public.

It’s always easy to say "I could’ve..." when you’re watching from the sidelines.
Ideas are just that: ideas.

Execution costs everything.
Time, doubt, energy, courage.

What most people don’t realize is:

The real work looks boring.
Just showing up, day after day, when no one’s clapping and regardless of your motivation.

A smart strategy means nothing without action.

You don’t rise by having the perfect plan.
You get there by moving when things are unclear.
By choosing momentum over perfection.

Plenty of people can think their way to a good idea.
Very few are willing to build their way through uncertainty.

That’s the difference.

PS: If you found this helpful, I share more insights to help you build the right mindset.
Follow me if you’re on a similar journey.

Image via Justin Welsh

Ankur Warikoo
Ankur Warikoo Being likable is often less about you.
More about how you make the other person feel:

Seen, heard, comfortable, respected.

It’s the smallest things that often leave the strongest impression, and these 5 hacks are simple ways to upgrade your conversations.

Which of these do you do already?

PS: If you found this helpful, follow me for more such insights.

Ankur Warikoo
Ankur Warikoo 6 graphs that will change the way you think about life.
(Inspired by Sahil Bloom) 

These visuals put into perspective how much time we really have left with the people we love.

A reminder that:

The moments we keep looking forward to are the ones we need to start living today.

Which graph was the most insightful for you?

PS: I share more insights to help you build a life you love.
Follow me if you’re on a similar journey.

Ankur Warikoo
Ankur Warikoo Someone sent an email early this week:

“Being around new people makes me quite uncomfortable.

Until now, my job was fully remote, which suited me well. 

We’ve recently shifted to a hybrid model, and I’ve realized that I become overly conscious.

My seniors have also started treating me like a pushover by assigning unnecessary deadlines and putting me under pressure, even when there’s no urgency.

How can I stand up for myself without damaging my work relationships?”

She further explained:

- I believe I am an introverted person and have always been that way.

- I often view myself as inferior to others in social or official gatherings.

- The way some seniors speak to me, often with a very authoritative tone, makes me feel disheartened.

- I think a part of me holds back out of respect.

I replied:

You’re not broken.
But you are stuck in a story that no longer serves you.

You call yourself an introvert. 

But introversion isn’t the issue here. 
Avoidance is. 

You're avoiding them because you're afraid of not measuring up. 

That’s self-doubt disguised as personality.

You feel inferior in social settings because others have seen more, done more. 
Sure.

But here’s the truth: 

Nobody ever learned how to swim by standing on the shore and watching others talk about the ocean.

You’ll learn by showing up as you are, not by waiting till you become "enough."

Now to the workplace.

You say you don’t push back because you don’t want to be disrespectful or argumentative. 

Being assertive is not being disrespectful. 

And being silent is not being respectful. 
It’s being invisible.

You are not helping your future self by avoiding temporary discomfort today. 

Here’s what I would do:

- Pick one moment this week to say something you normally wouldn’t.
Start small. But start.

- Script your pushback: “I understand the urgency, but I’ll need until X to do this well.” 
Firm. Respectful. Clear.

- Stop apologizing for not knowing enough. 
Nobody knows everything. 

You’re allowed to ask. 
You’re allowed to not have been everywhere. 
You’re allowed to learn in real time.

This version of you - the quiet one, the one who makes herself smaller - is a story that needs to stop. 

Time to write a better one.

Image via Colby Kultgen and Ben Meer

Ankur Warikoo
Ankur Warikoo Myth: You can give your 100% to work every day.

Between your home life, social life, and professional life, you don't operate at 100% efficiency.

If you force yourself to give your 100% every day, you will burn out.

Here’s how I approach it:
I know that my best effort looks different each day.
Depending on my energy levels, physical activity, social interactions, type of work, etc.

This is also why I advocate for setting habits over goals.

It helps me show up every day, work as much as I can mindfully (even if that’s a small step), and focus on the input over the output.

This way, you are still giving it 100% - of what you can give.

How much you work should never define your worth.

PS: I share more insights to help you become your best self.
Follow me if you’re on a similar journey.

Image credit: Sarah Arnold Hall on Instagram

Ankur Warikoo
Ankur Warikoo This is why comparison feels so much worse today:

When I was growing up, the world felt small.
No Internet. 
No WhatsApp. 
TV was the only window to the outside world, and it wasn't even personal.

Our world had maybe 50 people. 
School friends and neighbours - that's it.
So when we compared ourselves, it was to Sharma ji ka beta.

He topped the boards. That's it.
You weren't comparing abs, salary, vacations, or side hustles.

Then came the 2000s.
Social media turned 50 friends into 500.
We got access to everyone's lives. 
Promotions, heartbreaks, sneakers, success in real time.

We felt inspired. 
Then envious. 
Then empty. 
But we couldn't stop scrolling.

A decade later, social networks said,
"You're bored of friends? Here, meet strangers."
And suddenly, your world wasn't 50 people. It was 5 billion.

People like this always existed.
We just didn't know about them.
But now we do - all the time.

So what do you do?

1. Accept - This world is built for comparison.
It's not your fault you feel left behind, but it is your job to stop spiraling.

2. Remember - You're not in a race. You're in a relationship with yourself.
Only one person has your story. That person is you.

3. Know this - Even the best compare.
Winners just choose what to compare and when to stop.

So, no, you're not alone.
You're just online.

PS: Every week, I share such thoughts in my newsletter. You can receive that email for free by subscribing from the link in the comments.

Image via Pinterest

content:
Ankur Warikoo
Ankur Warikoo Many people I talk to don’t understand what really causes burnout.

Or they try to fix it with surface-level solutions that don’t work.

It’s not just about long hours or needing a vacation.

Burnout runs deeper.
And believing the wrong things about it only makes it worse.

This guide by Dora Vanourek explains 7 lies about burnout, and what to do instead.

If this resonated, repost to help someone else overcome burnout.

Ankur Warikoo
Ankur Warikoo Society’s timeline for success is completely made up.

She was one of China’s top table tennis players at 18.
But by 20, a change in the rules disrupted her playing style.
She decided to pivot and became a coach instead.

Years later, she moved to Chile and continued playing and training athletes.
By 34, she retired from the sport altogether.

For the next 20 years, she stayed away from the game.
Then came COVID.

She bought a ping pong table, just to pass her time. 
But she fell back in love with the game.

And at 54, when people think their life is over, she set a goal that most would laugh at.
To play in the Olympics.

Most people retire from sports in their 30s.
She chose to come back to it in her mid-50s.

At 58, she made her Olympic debut at Paris 2024.
That too at an age when most sportspersons retire.

Her name is Zhiying Zeng.
She is a world-class table tennis player, a teacher, and now, an Olympian.

It’s never too late to begin again.
It’s never too late to be extraordinary.

PS: If this resonated with you, I share more insights to help you build the right mindset.
Follow me to stay updated.

Ankur Warikoo
Ankur Warikoo We don’t need more information. 
We need a better perspective.

Most people go through life without ever learning this, but it changes everything once they do.

(Thanks to Liz Fosslien for these visuals): 

1. Failure isn’t the opposite of success; it’s part of it

2. Overthinking keeps you stuck; action moves you forward

3. The first step is usually the hardest, but also the most important

4. Judgment is lazy thinking; we rarely know the full story

5. Success isn’t about perfect circumstances; it’s about persistent belief

Which one did you need to hear the most?

Ankur Warikoo
Ankur Warikoo Daily reminder:

Not everyone will reciprocate your kindness.

Some won’t care.
Some might even manipulate it.

And yet…

Being kind, empathetic, and optimistic even when the world gets you down is not foolishness. 

It's an act of bravery.

It’s an act of believing in something bigger than yourself.

Because who would you be, if you are not kind?

PS: I share more insights to help you become your best self.
Follow me if you’re on a similar journey.
